name: Zagreb
fun_fact: Fun fact: Zagreb's St. Mark's Church has one of Europe's most photographed roofs - colorful tiles forming the medieval coats of arms of Croatia, Dalmatia and Slavonia, plus the emblem of Zagreb, constructed in 1880!

hero_dishes.name: 맚rukli
hero_dishes.description: The quintessential Zagreb comfort food - stretchy dough (preferably homemade) filled with cottage cheese, sour cream, and sometimes eggs, culminating in a perfectly crunchy crust balanced with a gooey warm filling.
hero_dishes.origin_story: This traditional cheese-filled dough dish is so beloved in Zagreb that an entire restaurant (La 맚ruk) is devoted to it, offering both boiled (kuhani) and baked (zape캜eni) varieties.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: La 맚ruk (specializes exclusively in 코trukli with sweet and savory flavors: cheese, blueberries, apples-cinnamon, walnuts-honey, roasted paprika, truffle paste, pumpkin seeds)

hero_dishes.name: Zagreba캜ki Odrezak (Zagreb Cutlet)
hero_dishes.description: This regional classic consists of cheese and ham sandwiched between slices of veal (or pork/turkey), which is rolled, breaded, and fried to perfection - reminiscent of a stuffed Vienna schnitzel or cordon bleu.
hero_dishes.origin_story: A traditional Croatian dish that became Zagreb's signature, showing the city's Austro-Hungarian culinary influences.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Gostionica Ficlek (uses house-cooked ham from Dolac Marketplace), Vinodol (one of Zagreb's crowning restaurants)

hero_dishes.name: Turkey with Mlinci
hero_dishes.description: Turkey (or duck) served with 'mlinci' - thin, usually homemade, dried flatbread broken into pieces and mixed with the roasted turkey juices, becoming soft and delicious while carrying the turkey flavor.
hero_dishes.origin_story: A classic of traditional Croatian cuisine in Zagreb and northern Croatia, this has become a trademark of Christmas meals and family gatherings.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Vinodol (recommended for the tastiest turkey with mlinci in city center), traditional family restaurants in Upper and Lower Town

hero_dishes.name: Sir i Vrhnje
hero_dishes.description: A beloved snack among locals - fresh locally made cheese mixed with sour cream, often with garlic mixed in and paprika sprinkled on top, served with fresh bread for dipping.
hero_dishes.origin_story: This humble dish represents Zagreb's love of simple, quality ingredients and social eating.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Local bistros, Dolac Market area, traditional Croatian restaurants

signature_drinks.name: Croatian Wine
signature_drinks.description: Croatia has excellent local wines, often enjoyed with meals in Zagreb's restaurants.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Paired with traditional dishes at restaurants like Vinodol and Pod Zidom, or enjoyed at wine bars throughout the city.

food_culture_notes: Zagreb's cuisine is influenced by neighboring Austria, Hungary, Italy, and Turkey
Dolac Market is called 'the stomach of Zagreb' - farmers gather daily except Sunday (best on Saturday mornings)
Upper Town and Lower Town house numerous excellent local restaurants
Traditional restaurants serve food that grandmothers and mothers would lovingly prepare
Pingvin is Zagreb's famous late-night sandwich spot - the most popular fast-food restaurant in the capital
Peka is a traditional cooking method using a clay or iron bell over open flames, making incredibly tender meat
